sp.l: ` Penbrooke, go raise an armie presentlie,
Pitch vp my tent, for in the field this night
I meane to rest, and on the morrow morne,
Ile march to meet proud Warwike ere he land
Those stragling troopes which he hath got in France.
But ere I goe Montague and Hastings,
You of all the rest are neerest allied
In bloud to Warwike, therefore tell me, if
You fauour him more then me or not:
Speake truelie, for I had rather haue you open
Enemies, then hollow friends.

sp.speaker: Monta.
sp.l: So God helpe Montague as he proues true.

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: And Hastings as hee fauours Edwards cause.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: It shall suffice, come then lets march awaie.
sp.stage: Enter Warwike and Oxford, with souldiers.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Trust me my Lords all hitherto goes well,
The common people by numbers swarme to vs,
But see where Sommerset and Clarence comes,
Speake suddenlie my Lords, are we all friends?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Feare not that my Lord.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Then gentle Clarence welcome vnto Warwike.
And welcome Summerset, I hold it cowardise,
To rest mistrustfull where a noble hart,
Hath pawnde an open hand in signe of loue,
Else might I thinke that Clarence▪ Edwards brother,
Were but a fained friend to our proceedings,
But welcome sweet Clarence my daughter shal be thine.
And now what rests but in nights couerture,
Thy brother being careleslie encampt,
His souldiers lurking in the towne about,
And but attended by a simple guarde,
We maie surprise and take him at our pleasure,
Our skouts haue found the aduenture verie easie,
Then crie king Henry with resolued nundes,
And breake we presentlie into his tent.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Why then lets on our waie in silent sort,
For Warwike and his friends God and saint George.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: This is his tent, and see where his guard doth
Stand, Courage my souldiers, now or neuer,
But follow me now, and Edward shall be ours.
All▪ A Warwike, a Warwike
sp.stage: Alarmes, and Gloster and Hastings shes.

sp.speaker: Oxf▪
sp.l: Who goes there?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Richard and Hastings let them go, heere is the Duke.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: The Duke, why Warwike when we parted
Last, thou caldst me king?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: I, but the case is altred now.
When you disgraste me in my embassage,
Then I disgraste you from being king,
And now am come to create you Duke of Yorke,
Alasse how should you gouerne anie kingdome,
That knowes not how to vse embassadors,
Nor how to vse your brothers brotherlie,
No●how to shrowd your selfe from enimies.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Well Warwike, let fortune doe her worst,
Edward in mind will beare himselfe a king.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Then for his minde be Edward Englands king,
But Henry now shall weare the English crowne.
Go conuaie him to our brother archbishop of Yorke,
And when I haue fought with Penbrooke & his followers,
Ile come and tell thee what the ladie Bona saies,
And so for a while farewell good Duke of Yorke.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What followes now, all hithertoo goes well,
But we must dispatch some letters to France,
To tell the Queene of our happy fortune,
And bid hir come with speed to ioine with vs.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: I thats the first thing that we haue to doe,
And free king Henry from imprisonment,
And see him seated in his regall throne,
Come let vs haste awaie, and hauing past these cares,
Ile post to Yorke, and see how Edward fares.
sp.stage: Enter Gloster, Hastings, and sir William Stanly.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Lord Hastings▪ and 〈◊〉 William Stanly,
Know that the cause I sent for you is this.
I looke my brother with a slender traine,
Should come a hunting in this forrest heere.
The Bishop of Yorke be friends him much,
And lets him vse his pleasure in the chase,
Now I haue priuilie sent him word,
How I am come with you to rescue him.
And see where the huntsman and he doth come.

sp.speaker: Hunts
sp.l: This waie my Lord the deere is gone.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: No this waie huntsman, see where the
Keepers stand. Now brother and the rest,
What, are you prouided to depart?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I, I▪ the horse stands at the parke corner,
Come, to Linne▪ and so take shipping into Flanders▪

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Come then: Hastings, and Stanlie, I will
Requite your loues. Bishop farewell,
Sheeld thee from Warwikes frowne,
And praie that I maie repossesse the crowne.
Now huntsman what will you doe?

sp.speaker: Hunts
sp.l: Marrie my Lord, I thinke I had as good
Goe with you, as tarrie heere to be hangde.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Come then lets awaie with speed.
sp.stage: Enter the Queene and the Lord Riuers.

sp.speaker: Riuers.
sp.l: Tel me good maddam, why is your grace
So passionate of late?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Why brother Riuers, heare you not the newes,
Of that successe king Edward had of late?

sp.speaker: Riu.
sp.l: What● losse of some pitcht battaile against Warwike,
Tush, feare not faire Queen, but cast those cares aside.
King Edwards noble mind his honours doth display▪
And Warwike maie loose, though then he got the day.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: If that were all, my griefes were at an end:
But greater troubles will I feare befall.

sp.speaker: Riu
sp.l: What, is he taken prisoner? by the foe,
To the danger of his royall person then:

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I, thears my griefe, king Edward is surprisde,
And led awaie, as prisoner vnto Yorke.

sp.speaker: Riu.
sp.l: The newes is passing strange. I must confesse:
Yet comfort your selfe, for Edward hath more friends,
Then Lancaster at this time must perceiue,
That some will set him in his throne againe▪

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: God grant they maie, but gentle brother come,
And let me leane vpon thine arme a while,
Vntill I come vnto the sanctuarie,
There to preserue the fault within my wombe,
K. Edwards seed true heire to Englands crowne.
sp.stage: Enter Edward and Richard, and Hastings with a troope of Hollanders.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Thus far from Belgia haue we past the seas,
And marcht from Raunspur hauen vnto Yorke:
But soft the gates are shut, I like not this.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Sound vp the drum and call them to the wals.
Enter the Lord Maire of Yorke vpon the wals.

sp.speaker: Mair.
sp.l: My Lords we had notice of your comming,
And thats the cause we stand vpon our garde,
An I shut the gates for to preserue the towne.
Henry now is king, and we are sworne to him.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Why my Lord Maire, if Henry be your king,
Edward I am sure at least, is Duke of Yorke.

sp.speaker: Mair.
sp.l: Truth my Lord, we know you for no lesse.

sp.speaker: Edw▪
sp.l: I craue nothing but my Dukedome.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: But when the Fox hath gotten in his head,
Heele quicklie make the bodie follow after.

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: Why my Lord Maire, what stand you vpon points?
Open the gates, we are king Henries friends.

sp.speaker: Mair.
sp.l: Saie you so, then Ile open them presentlie.
sp.stage: Ri. By my faith, a wise stout captain & soone perswaded. The Maire opens the dore, and brings the keies in his hand.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: So my Lord Maire, these gates must not be shut,
But in the time of warre, giue me the keies:
What, feare not man for Edward will defend
the towne and you, despight of all your foes.
sp.stage: Enter sir Iohn Mountgommery with drumme and souldiers.
sp.l: How now Richard, who is this?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Brother, this is sir Iohn Mountgommery,
A trustie friend vnlesse I be deceiude.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Welcome sir Iohn▪ Wherfore come you in armes?

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.l: To helpe king Edward in this time of stormes,
As euerie loyall subiect ought to doe.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Thankes braue Mountgommery,
But I onlie claime my Dukedom,
Vntil it please God to send the rest.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.l: Then sa●e you wel▪ Drum strike vp and let vs
March away, I came to serue a king and not a Duke.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Nay sta●e sir Iohn, and let vs first debate,
With what security we maie doe this thing.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.l: What stand you on debating to be briefe,
Except you presently proclaime your selfe our king,
Ile hence againe, and keepe them backe that come to
Succour you, why should we fight when
You pretend no title?

sp.speaker: Rich
sp.l: Fie brother, fie, stand you vpon tearmes?
Resolue your selfe, and let vs claime the crowne.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: I am resolude once more to claime the crowne,
And win it too▪ or else to loose my life.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.l: I now my soueraigne speaketh like himselfe,
And now will I be Edwards Champion,
Sound Trumpets, for Edward shall be proclaimd.

Edward the fourth by the grace of God, king of England and France, and Lord of Ireland, and whosoeuer gainsa●es king Edwards Might: by this I challenge him to single sight, long liue Edward the fourth.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Long liue Edward the fourth.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: We thanke you all. Lord Maire leade on the waie.
For this night weele harbour here in Yorke,
And then is earlie as the morning sunne,
Liftes vp his beames aboue this horison
Weele march to London, to meete with Warwike:
And pull sal●e Henry from the Regall throne.
sp.stage: Enter Warwike and Clarence, with the Crowne, and then king Henry, and Oxford, and Summerset, and the yong Earle of Richmond.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thus from the prison to this prince lie seat,
By Gods great mercies am I brought
Againe, Clarence and Warwike doe you
Keepe the crowne, and gouerue and protect
My realme in peace, and I will spend the
Remnant of my daies, to sinnes rebuke
And my Creators praise.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: What answeres Clarence to his soueraignes will?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Clarence agrees to what king Henry likes.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My Lord of Summerset, what prettie
Boie is that you seeme to be so carefull of?

sp.speaker: Sum
sp.l: And it please your grace, it is youg Henry,
Earle of Richmond.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Henry of Richmond, Come hither pretie Ladde.
If heauenlie powers doe aime aright
To my diuining thoughts, thou pretie boy,
Shalt proue this Countries blisse,
Thy head is made to weare a princelie crowne,
Thy lookes are all repleat with Maiestie,
Make much of him my Lords,
For this is he shall helpe you more,
Then you are hurt by me.
sp.stage: Enter one with a letter to Warwike.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: What Counsell Lords, Edward from Belgia,
With hastie Germaines and blunt Hollanders,
Is past in safetie through the narrow seas,
And with his troopes doe march amaine towardes London,
And manie giddie people follow him.

sp.speaker: Oxf.
sp.l: Tis best to looke to this betimes,
For if this ●ue doe kindle any further,
It will be hard for vs to quench it out.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: In Warwike shire I haue true harted friends,
Not mutinous in peace, yet bold in warre,
Them will I muster vp, and thou sonne Clarence shalt
In Essex, Suffolke, Norfolke, and in Kent,
Stir vp the knights and gentlemen to come with thee▪
And thou brother Montague, in Leister shire,
Buckingham and Northampton shire shalt finde,
Men well inclinde to doe what thou commands,
And thou braue Oxford wondrous well belou'd,
Shalt in thy countries muster vp thy friends.
My soueraigne with his louing Citizens,
Shall rest in London till we come to him.
Faire Lords take leaue and stand not to replie,
Farewell my soueraigne.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Farewel my Hector, my Troyes true hope,

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Farewell sweet Lords, lets meet at Couentrie.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Sease on the shamefast Henry,
And once againe conuaie him to the Tower,
Awaie with him, I will not heare him speake.
And now towards Couentrie let vs bend our course
To meet with Warwike and his confederates.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Where is the post that came from valiant Oxford?
How farre hence is thy Lord my honest fellow?

sp.speaker: Oxf post.
sp.l: By this at Daintrie marching hitherward.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Where is our brother Montague?
Where is the post that came from Montague?

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: I left him at Donsmore with his troopes.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Say Summerfield where is my louing son?
And by thy gesse, how farre is Clarence hence?

sp.speaker: Sommer.
sp.l: At Southham my Lord I left him with
His force, and doe expect him two houres hence.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Then Oxford is at hand, I heare his drum.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: See brother, where the surlv Warwike mans the wal.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: O vnbid spight, is spotfull Edward come!
Where slept our scouts or how are they sedus●e,
That we could haue no newes of their repaire?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Now Warwike wilt thou be sorrie for thy faults,
And call Edward king and he will pardon thee.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Naie rather wilt thou draw thy forces backe?
Confesse who set thee vp and puld thee downe?
Call Warwike patron and be penitent,
And thou shalt still remaine the Duke of Yorke.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I had thought at least be would haue said the king.
Or did he make the best against his will.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Twas Warwike gaue the kingdome to thy brother.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Why then tis mine, if but by Warwikes gift.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: I but thou art no Atlas for so great a waight,
And weakling, Warwike takes his gift againe,
Henry is my king, Warwike his subiect▪

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: I prethe gallant Warwike tell me this,
What is the bodie when the head is off?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Alasse that Warwike had no more foresight,
But whilst he sought to steale the single ten,
The king was finelie fingerd from the decke?
You left poore Henry in the Bishops pallace,
And ten to one you'le meet him in the Tower.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Tis euen so, and yet you are olde Warwike still.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: O cheerefull colours, see where Oxford comes.
sp.stage: Enter Oxford with drum and souldiers & al crie,

sp.speaker: Oxf.
sp.l: Oxford, Oxford, for Lancaster. Exit.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: The Gates are open, see they enter in,
Lets follow them and bid them battaile in the streetes.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: No, so some other might set vpon our backes,
Weele staie till all be entered, and then follow them.
sp.stage: Enter Summerset▪ with drum and souldiers.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.l: Summerset, Summerset for Lancaster.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Two of thy name both Dukes of Summerset,
Haue solde their liues vnto the house of Yorke,
And thou shalt be the third and my sword hold.
sp.stage: Enter Montague with drum and souldiers.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Montague, Montague, for Lancaster. Exit.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Traitorous Montague, thou and thy brother
Shall deerelie abie this rebellious act.
sp.stage: Enter Clarence with drum and souldiers.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: And loe where George of Clarence sweepes
Along, of power enough to bid his brother battell.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Clarence, Clarence, for Lancaster.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Et tu Brute, wilt thou stab Caesar too?
A parlie sirra to George of Clarence.
sp.stage: Sound a Parlie, and Richard and Clarence whispers togither, and then Clarence takes his red Rose out of his hat, and throwes it at Warwike.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: C●m Clarence come, thou wilt if Warwike call.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Father of Warwike, know you what this meanes▪
● throw mine infamie at thee,
I will not ruinate my fathers house,
Who gaue his bloud to lime the stones togither,
And set vp Lancaster. Thinkest thou
That Clarence is so harsh vnnaturall,
To lift his sword against his brothers life,
And so proud harted Warwike I defie thee,
And to my brothers turne my blushing cheekes?
Pardon me Edward, for I haue done amisse,
And Richard doe not frowne vpon me,
For hence forth I will proue no more vnconstant.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Welcome Clarence, and ten times more welcome,
Then if thou neuer hadst deserud out hate.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Welcome good Clarence, this is bretherlie.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Oh passing traytor, periurd and vniust.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Now Warwike, wilt thou leaue
The towne and fight? or shall we beate the
Stones about thine eares?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Why I am not coopt vppe heere for defence,
I will awaie to Barnet presently,
And bid thee battaile Edward it thou darest.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Yes Warwike he dares, and leades the waie,
Lords to the field, saint George and victorie.
Alarmes, and then enter Warwike wounded.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Ah, who is ●? Come to m● friend or foe,
And tell me who is victor Yorke or Warwike?
Why aske I that? my ma glad bodie shewes,
That I must yeeld my bodie to the earth.
And by my fall the conquest to my foes,
Thus yeelds the Cedar to the axes edge.
Whose armes giue shelter to the princelie eagle,
Vnder whose 〈◊〉 ad● the ramping Lion slept,
Whose top branch ouerpeerd Ioues sreading tree.
The wrinkles in my browes now fild with bloud,
Were likened oft to kinglie sepulchers.
For who liu'd king, but I could dig his graue?
And who durst smile, when Warwike bent his brow?
Lo now my glorie smeerd in dust and bloud,
My parkes my walkes, my mannors that I had,
Euen now forsake me and of all my lands,
Is nothing left me but my bodies length.

sp.speaker: Oxf.
sp.l: Ah Warwike, Warwike, cheere vp thy selfe and li●e,
For yet thears hope enough to win the daie.
Our warlike Queene with troopes is come from France,
And at South●h●mpton landed all hi● traine,
And mightst thou l●ue then would we neuer flie.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Which then I would not flie nor haue I now,
But Hercules himselfe must yeeld to ods,
For m●●e wounds receiu'd, and manie moe repaid,
Hath robd my strong knit ●●news of their strength,
And spite of sp●tes needes must I yeeld to death.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.l: Thy brother Montague hath breathd his last,
And at the pangs of death I heard him crie
And saie, commend me to my valiant brother,
And more he would haue spoke and 〈◊〉 he said,
Which sounded like a 〈…〉 a vault,
That could not be distinguisht for the sound,
And so the valiant Montague gaue vp the ghost.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: What is pompe, rule, raigne, but earth and dust▪
And liue we how we can, yet the w● m●st.
Sweet rest his soule, she Lords and 〈◊〉 your selues,
For Warwike bids you all farewell to mee●●n Heauen.

sp.speaker: Oxf▪
sp.l: Come noble Summerset, lets take our horse,
And cause retrait be sounded through the campe,
That all our friends that yet remaine aliue▪,
Maie be awarn'd and ●aue themselues by flight.
That done, with them weele post vnto the Queene,
And once mo●eui● our fortune in the field
sp.stage: Enter Edward Clarence, Gloster, with souldiers.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Thus still our fortune 〈◊〉 vs victorie,
And g●●ts our temples with triumphant ioies
The bigboond traytor Warwike hath breathde his last,
An I heauen this daie hath sm●●de vpon v●●all,
But in this cleere and brightsome ●a●e,
I see a blacke suspitious cloud appeare
That will enc●unter with our glorious sunne
Before he gaine his ●asefull w● ste●e be ●●es,
I mean those powers which the Queen hath got in France
Are landed, and meane once more to menace vs.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Oxford and Summerset are sled to hi●,
And 〈◊〉 likelie if she haue time to breath,
Her fact on will be full as strong as ours.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: We are aduertisde by our louing friends,
That they doe hold their course towards Tow●burie.
Th●ther will we 〈◊〉 for willingnes rids waie,
And in euerie countie as we passe along,
O●● str engthes shall be augmented.
Come lets goe, for if we slacke this faire
B●●ght Summers daie, sharpe winters
Sho●ers will make our hope for haie.
sp.stage: Enter the Queene, Prince Edward Oxford and Summerset, with drum and souldiers.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Welcome to England, my louing friends of France,
And welcome Summerset, and Oxford too.
Once more haue we spread our sailes abroad,
And though our tackling be almost consumde,
And Warwike as our maine mast ouerthrowne,
Yet warlike Lords raise you that sturdie post,
That beares the sailes to bring vs vnto rest,
And Ned and I as willing P●lots should
For once with carefull mindes guide on the sterne,
To beare vs through that dangerous gulfe
That heretofore hath swallowed vp our friends.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: And if there be, as God forbid there should,
Amongst vs a timorous or fearefull man,
Let him depart before the battels ioine,
●east he in time of need intise another,
And so withdraw the souldiers harts from vs.
I will not stand aloofe and bid you fight,
But with my sword presse in the thickest thronges,
And single Edward from his strongest guard,
And hand to hand enforce him for to yeeld,
Or leaue my bodie as witnesse of my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Oxf.
sp.l: Women and children of so high resolue,
And Warriors faint, why twere perpetuall
Shame? Oh braue yong Prince, thy
Noble grandfather doth liue againe in thee,
Long maiest thou liue to beare his image,
And to renew his glories.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.l: And he that turnes and flies when such do fight,
Let him to bed, and like the Owle by daie
Be hist, and wondered at if he arise.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: My Lords, Duke Edward with a mighty power,
Is marching hitherwards to fight with you.

sp.speaker: Oxf.
sp.l: I thought it was his pollicie, to take vs vnprouided,
But here will we stand and fight it to the death.
sp.stage: Enter king Edward, Cla. Glo. Hast. and Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: See brothers, yonder stands the thornie wood,
Which by Gods assistance and your prowesse,
Shall with our swords yer night be cleane cut downe.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Lords, Knights & gentlemen, what I should say,
My teares gainesaie, for as you see, I drinke
The water of mine eies. Then no more
But this. Henry your king is prisoner
In the tower, his land and all our friends
Are quite distrest, and yonder standes
The Wolfe that makes all this,
Then on Gods name Lords togither cry saint George.
All Saint George for Lancaster.

div.p: Alarmes to the battell, Yorke flies, then the chambers be discharged. Then enter the king▪ Cla & Glo. & the rest, & make a great shout, and crie, for Yorke, for Yorke, and then the Queene is taken, & the prince, & Oxf. & Sum. and then sound and enter all againe.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Lo here a period of tumultuous broiles,
Awaie with Oxford to Hames castell straight,
For Summerset off with his guiltie head.
Awaie I will not heare them speake.

sp.speaker: Oxf.
sp.l: For my part Ile not trouble thee with words.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.l: Not I, but stoope with patience to my death.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Now Edward what satisfaction canst thou make,
●or stirring vp my subiects to rebellion?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Speake like a subiect proud ambitious Yorke,
Suppose that I am now my fathers mouth,
Resigne thy chaire▪ and where I stand kneele thou,
Whilst I propose the selfesame words to thee,
Which traytor thou woudst haue me answere to.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Oh that thy father had bin so resolu●d▪

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: That you might still haue kept your
Peticote, and nere haue slolne the
Breath from Lancaster.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Let Aesop fable in a winters night.
His cuttish Riddles sorts not with this place.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: By heauen brat Ile plague you for that word.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I▪ thou wast borne to be a plague to men.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: For Gods sake take a waie this captiue scold.

sp.speaker: Prin
sp.l: Nay take away this skolding Crooktbacke rather.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Peace wilfull boy, or I will tame your tongue.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Vntuterd lad thou art too malepert.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: I know my dutie, you are all vndutifull.
Lasciuious Edward, and thou periurd George,
And thou mishapen Dicke, I tell you all,
I am your better, traytors as you be.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Take that, the litnes of this railer heere.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Oh kill me too.

sp.speaker: Glo
sp.l: Marrie and shall.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Hold Richard hold, for we haue doone too much alreadie.

sp.speaker: Glo
sp.l: Why should she liue to fill the world with words?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: What doth she swound: make meanes for Her recouerie?

sp.speaker: Glo
sp.l: Clarence, excuse me to the king my brother,
I must to London on a serious matter,
Ere you come there▪ you shall heare more newes.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: About what, prethe tell me?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: The Towerman, the Tower, Ile root them out

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Ah Ned, speake to thy mother boy? ah
Thou canst not speake.
Traytors, Tyrants, bloudie Homicides,
They that stabd Caesar shed no bloud at all,
For he was a man, this in respect a childe,
And men nere spend then furie on a child,
Whats worse then tyrant that I maie name,
You haue no children Deuils, if you had,
The thought of them would then haue stopt your rage,
But if you euer hope to haue a sonne,
Looke in his youth to haue him so cut off,
As Traitors you haue doone this sweet young prince.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Awaie, and beare her hence.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Naie nere beare me hence, dispatch
Me heere, heere sheath thy sword,
Ile pardon thee my death. Wilt thou not?
Then Clarence, doe thou doe it?

sp.speaker: Cla
sp.l: By Heauen I would not doe thee so much ease.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Good Clarence doe, sweet Clarence kill me too.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Didst thou not heare me sweare I would not do it?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I, but thou vsest to forsweare thy selfe,
Twas sinne before, but now tis charitie.
Whea●s the Diuels butcher, hardfauored Richard,
Richard where art thou? He is not heere,
Murder is his almes deed, petitioners
For bloud he nere put backe.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Awaie I saie, and take her hence perforce.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: So come to you and yours, as to this prince.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Clarence, whithers Gloster gone?

sp.speaker: Cla
sp.l: Marrie my Lord to London, and as I gesse, to
Make a bloudie supper in the Tower.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: He is sudden if a thing come in his head.
Well, discharge the common souldiers with paie
And thankes, and now let vs towards London,
To see our gentle Queene how shee doth fare,
For by this I hope shee hath a sonne for vs.
sp.stage: Enter Gloster to king Henry in the Tower.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Good day my Lord. What at your booke so hard?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I my good Lord. Lord I should saie rather,
Tis sinne to flatter, good was little better,
Good Gloster, and good Diuell, were all alike,
What scene of Death hath Rosius now to act?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Suspition alwaies haunts a guiltie mind.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: The birde once limde doth feare the fatall bush,
And I the haplesse maile to one poore birde,
Haue now the fatall obiect in mine eie,
Where my poore young was limde, was caught & kild.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Why, what a foole was that of Cree●e?
That taught his sonne the office
Of a birde, and yet for all that the poore
Fowle was drownde.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I Dedalus, my poore sonne Icarus,
Thy father Minos that denide our course,
Thy brother Edward, the sunne that ●earde his wings,
And thou the enuious gulfe that swallowed him.
Oh better can my brest abide thy daggers point,
Then can mine cares that tragike historie.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Why dost thou thinke I am an executioner?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: A persecutor I am sure thou art,
And if murdering innocents be executions,
Then I know thou art an executioner.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Thy sonne I kild for his presumption.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Hadst thou bin kild when first thou didst presume,
Thou hadst not liude to kill a sonne of mine,
And thus I prophesie of theo.
That manie a Widdow for her husbands death,
And many an infants water standing eie,
Widowes for their husbands, children for their fathers,
Shall curse the time that euer thou wert borne.
The owle s●●ikt at thy birth, an euill signe,
The night Crow cride, aboding lucklesse tune,
Dogs howld and hideous tempests shooke down trees,
The Rauen rookt her on the Chimnies top,
And chattering Pi●s in dismall discord sung,
Thy mother felt more then a mothers paine,
And yet brought ●orth lesse then a mothers hope,
To wit▪ an vndigest created lumpe.
Not like the fruit of such a goodly tree,
Teeth hadst thou in thy head when thou wast borne,
Thus haue we swept suspition from our seat,
And made our footstoole of securitie.
Come hither Besse, and let me kisse my boie,
Young Ned, for thee, thine Vncles and my selfe,
Haue in our armors watcht the Winters night,
Marcht all a foote in summers skalding heat,
That thou mightst repossesse the crowne in peace,
And of out labours thou shalt reape the gaine.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Ile blast his haruest and your head were laid,
For yet I am not lookt on in the world.
This shoulder was ordaind so thicke to heaue,
And heaue it shall some waight or breake my backe,
Worke thou the waie, and thou shalt execute.
Edward, Clarence and Gloster, loue my louelie Queene,
And kisse your princely nephew brothers both.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: The dutie that I owe vnto your, Maiestie,
I seale vpon the rosiate lips of this sweet babe.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Thankes noble Clarence worthie brother thankes.

sp.speaker: Gloster.
sp.l: And that I loue the fruit from whence thou
Sprangst, witnesse the louing kisse I giue the child.
To saie the truth so Iudas kist his maister,
And so he cride all haile▪ and meant all ha●●e.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Nowe am I seated as my soule delights,
Hauing my countries peace, and brothers loues.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What will your grace haue done with Margaret▪
Ranard her father to the king of France,
Hath pawnd the Cyssels and Ierusalem,
And hither haue they sent it for her ransome.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Awaie with her, and wa●te hir hence to France,
And now what rests but that we spend the time,
With stately Triumphs and mirthfull comick● shewes,
Such as befits the pleasures of the Court.
Sound drums and Trumpets, farewell to sower annoy,
For heere I hope begins our lasting ioie.
